discussion.content: I think A and B
A and B is correct
If A/B are correct, why would you link it just to export the original path
AB. F will not work on most systems because /opt is not in the default path. Making the file executable wouldn't help if bash can't find it. Therefore, A and B are best answers.
https://askubuntu.com/a/878022 - F and A

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator downloads an application's source files, compiles the application, and installs it per the application's installation instructions. When trying to run the application, the system states:
$ occmd
bash: occmd: command not found`¦
Running the locate command shows it does exist in the following location:
/opt/occmd/bin/occmd
Which of the following should the administrator do to allow the command to run properly? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: B. /etc/resolv.conf

conf is resolver configuration file for Linux and UNIX like operating systems. It is used to configure dns name servers. The file /etc/resolv. conf file contains information that is read by the resolver routines the first time they are invoked by a process.

questions.question_text: A Linux administrator tries to ping a hostname in a network but receives the message: hostname not found. The administrator is sure the name exists on the network and wants to verify if the DNS server is correctly configured on the client. Which of the following files should the administrator use to verify this information?

discussion.content: it does not specify application but just states HTTPS using server, 443 protocol seems to be blocked in the firewall. Answer C should be the first step then check application if it is set to allow HTTPS or use HTTPS
Hello guys the port 443 HTTPS is blocked by the firewall so answer is C. Allow port 443 through the firewall.

comments.content: The application is the www service running on apache or nginx. Since port 80 is open IE www service, the web server is up and running, I think its the port 443 ssl/https is blocked, answer C

discussion.content:
According to the following explanation, A should be the answer:

NMAP States explained:
The state is either open, filtered, closed, or unfiltered. 
- Open means that an application on the target machine is listening for connections/packets on that port.
- Filtered means that a firewall, filter, or other network obstacle is blocking the port so that Nmap cannot tell whether it is open or closed.
- Closed ports have no application listening on them, though they could open up at any time.
- Ports are classified as unfiltered when they are responsive to Nmap's probes, but Nmap cannot determine whether they are open or closed.

choices.B: Configure the application to run on an active port
choices.A: Start the application to run on port 443

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. touch /.autorelabel && reboot
D. restorecon / && reboot

I'm going with answer C here as the .autorelabel file will force a RECURSIVE check of the whole system on boot whereas answer D lacks the -R flag that restorecon needs to work RECURSIVELY over the whole filesystem. Without -R it just works on a single file/dir.

Correct Answer is D
This manual page describes the restorecon program.
This program is primarily used to reset the security context (type) (extended attributes) on one or more files.

It can be run at any time to correct errors, to add support for new policy, or with the -n option it can just check whether the file contexts are all as you expect.

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer is C, this does exactly what the question is asking for.
D is wrong for 2 reasons:
1. in order to run restorecon on the whole system you would need -R option 
2. there is no need to reboot after a restorecon.

The correct answer is D for sure.
https://www.thegeekdiary.com/restorecon-command-examples-in-linux/

the question is asking to restore the security context on the whole filesystem.
so the answer is C

https://www.thegeekstuff.com/2017/05/restorecon-examples/
- restorecon stands for Restore SELinux Context.
C is when used to recover password to make selinux save the new context for the new set password and add it to default context after reboot. So D is correct.

comments.content: I concur. If you check the man page, it matches the definition to D.

discussion.content: Should be C

questions.question_text: A Linux administrator is restoring the SELinux contexts on an entire system. Which of the following commands is the BEST option to complete this task?

discussion.content: for ip in $(grep "Linux" hosts.csv | cut -d, -f1); do echo -n $ip,; done

Selected Answer: A
Read the command syntax, cut is used to cut parts of lines from specified files or piped data and print the result to standard output. Sed is used for insertion, deletion, search and replace(substitution). We meed to use the standard output from the first part of the command to feed the second part. Thus A
It's A. The sed command in C will bring up an "sed: -e expression #1, char 0: no previous regular expression" error because there is no expression defined to match with.

questions.question_text:
An administrator has a CSV file named hosts.csv. The contents of hosts.csv include the following:
192.168.2.57,lnx1prd.example.com,Linux,Production
192.168.2.58,lnx2prd.example.com,Linux,Production
192.168.1.4,server15.example.com,Windows,Development
The administrator needs to create a second comma-separated list of only the Linux server IP addresses. Which of the following commands would achieve this need?
